Travellers can be created using a Traveller type of Actor. An NPC is a simplified Traveller which lacks most of the information around the life path character generation.

Rolling Characteristics

You can roll characteristics by clicking the dice symbol next to the characteristics on the Traveller sheet. This will roll 2D6 for each characteristic.

They will automatically calculate the Dice Modifier for that characteristic.

You can use a Package actor to define different characteristic rolls for non-human characters. Set it as a racial package, and define what dice rolls are used for each characteristic. When the Package is dragged onto a Traveller or NPC sheet, the sheet will remember what dice to roll each time.

Characteristics supported are: STR, DEX, END, INT, EDU, SOC, CHA, TER, PSI, WLT, LCK, MRL, STY, RES, FOL, REP

Background Skills

Click the Background Skills tick box to display which skills can be selected as background skills.

By default, characters are created at 18 years old.

Combat is implemented in as much as attacks can be made, damage rolled and applied to Travellers, Creatures and Vehicles.

Some Assumptions

Battle Maps

Unlike some other game systems, Traveller doesn't require the use of battle maps in a game at all. Many players and GMs use Theatre of the Mind, using tokens on a scene only to track damage and list the available targets.

Some people struggle to imagine scenes in their head though, or just prefer to have a pretty map with well defined placement of characters and enemies. If using such a 'battle map', whether you use a grid or not is optional.

The MgT2e system doesn't enforce either, though there are some features that will make use of a scaled map if you are using one.

The general assumption is a 1.5m grid (square or hex), but again this is not enforced.

Some Map Features

Making Attacks

When making an attack, if you have a single token selected, then that token will be assumed to be the one making the attack.

If you have other tokens selected as targets (press 'T' when hovering over them), then these will be assumed as potential targets.

This allows the attack dialog to display the distance to each target, allowing you to more easily select the range of an attack.

Grenades

If the damage from a grenade, or other weapon with a blast radius, is dragged onto a map, then the blast radius will be automatically displayed on the map.

If the attack missed, then there is a world setting to allow for random displacement. However, this doesn't account for walls.

The Traveller trade system is implemented using the World and Spacecraft actors, and the Cargo Item types.

Passengers

To generate passengers, you need two or more Worlds defined, each with non-zero populations. They should have different X and Y coordinates as well.

If you have World A and World B, open both world sheets, and drag the planet icon from World B to World A. On the Freight tab on World A, you should see a list of passengers created. This will be the passengers wanting to travel to World B.

You can then drag the passengers from the world sheet onto a spacecraft sheet. The spacecraft will have cash added to it as the passengers pay for their trip.

Later, you can drag the passengers from the spacecraft to World B. The passengers will be removed from the spacecraft.

We do not use the random passenger table in the core rules. Instead, a much more flexible system is used to generate passengers, based on their class.

Missing Features

  • There are no modifiers to numbers or types of passengers according to Steward skill, or whether the ship has luxury staterooms.

  • There is no tracking of how many staterooms (or cold berths) are taken up with passengers

  • We don't account for the luggage of High Passengers.

Freight

Freight is calculated in the same way as for Passengers. Drag the world you are going to, to the world you are currently at. Freight lots will be calculated for that trip, and added to the World sheet.

Missing Features

  • We don't currently handle Mail.

  • Doesn't calculate distances across sector boundaries.

Speculative Trade

Speculative trade isn't based on a destination world, so there is only one set of speculative trade goods. These are displayed on the Trade tab of a world.

The list of Trade Goods is defined in an item folder called Trade Goods. If this is not present in the world, then the world in this compendium pack is. You can copy the compendium version into your world, and modify the list of goods that are available.

Missing Features:

  • An easy way to compare with another world. Should be possible to see the 'expected' prices for a world, and automate coming up with suggested list of goods to buy.

Extra Features

  • Each world can specify a specific Trade Goods folder. If this is set, then rather than using the default list of trade goods, this world will use its own list. This allows different worlds to have a different set of trade goods.

  • If you drag a Cargo item to a world from the side bar (not from an actor), then it will be added as a unique local good. These are always available for purchase from this world, and allows a world to have a few extra unique goods.

  • Spare Parts are added to the list of goods available. They are always the same sale and purchase price, so are not useful for trade. Internally, the number of spare parts is generated based on the world population code, and the size of the starport.

  • If you create tables "Trade Sell Modifiers" or "Trade Buy Modifiers", and add them to the world, then these will be used to randomly add a DM to the roll to Sell and Buy prices respectively. This allows the trade system to be modified if you want to make it easier or harder. Example tables are included in the compendium. Copy them to your world to use them.

The World Sheet has basic world generation built in.

Click the 'Generate' button to randomly generate a new world.

Facilities and bases will be generated based on the starport type.

Refuelling

Options to buy fuel are available at the world.

Factions

If there are no factions on a world, factions will be randomly generated when the world is generated.

Patrons

Patrons can be added, aren't currently randomly generated.

This journal covers how MgT2e implements the various rules in Mongoose Traveller 2e. Not all rules are implemented, and of those that are, they may not be enforced. This isn't a computer game, but a TTRPG that happens to run on a computer. Where possible, some things are implemented so that the GM and Players are allowed to interpret exactly what happens.

This journal doesn't cover what the rules are, it's not a replacement for the Core Rules book. When used in reference with that book (soon to be available as a Compendium), it should help guide how to use Foundry with Mongoose Traveller.

Computers and Software

Computers

A Computer is any item that has the Computer option enabled.

Generic Items, Augments, Armour and Weapons can have computers enabled on them. Once the computer is enabled, the bandwidth capability of the software can be set on a range of 0 to 4.

Currently, this value is for informational purposes only. No limitations are enforced as to what software can be run on a computer.

Once an item has an embedded computer enabled, it will also list the software packages that are currently installed on it.

Using Computers

If a computer has software installed on it, then the list will be displayed, along with the option to make skill checks direct from the computer.

The type of software package (see below) will determine how these skills are used.

Software

Software is a special type of item that can be installed on anything with an embedded computer, or on a spacecraft.

There are two types of softwrae: Personal and Spacecraft.

Personal software can be installed onto embedded computers.

Spacecraft software only runs on a ship's computer.

Software Properties

Interface Type

If the software is an interface, then you can set the type of interface it provides. You can select the interface type from the drop down. A computer needs to have an interface installed on it for it to be usable.

Currently, there is basic enforcement of this. If multiple interfaces are installed on a computer, the best is used.

Installed On

If a software item is owned by an Actor, then the "Installed On" drop down will list all the other items this Actor has that have the ability to run software. Select the one that you want to run this software package on.

Software Features

The features of the software define what it does. Normally, most software provides the ability to run skills.

Generic

This software doesn't do anything that is covered by rules automation.

Agent

An agent skill can only be used with Electronics (Computers). Gives the user +1 if they have the skill,, or the agent does the check itself if not.

Expert Package

This is an expert package, and obeys the rules of expert packages. The skill can be rolled from the computer that it is installed on.

Skill Augment

A skill augment gives a direct bonus to a skill check, but the user needs to have the skill.

Task Skill

The computer makes the skill check itself, without any reference to the Actor's own skill.
Minimal support, waiting for the next version of the Vehicle Handbook to come out.

Space combat is partly implemented. There are lots of options which aren't quite there yet, but there should be enough to be able to run the bits that aren't manually.

Maps and Tokens

Maps aren't necessary for space combat, but they can be used if you want to determine distance between ships.

Creating a Scene

Create a scene with a grid scale of around 1,000km may be convenient. A scale of 1,600km means that planets are 1 grid square/hex wide for every point of size, which has a nice symmetry but isn't needed.

There is a @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-macros.Macro.qaDapPxzkNdklekX]{Scale Worlds} macro that will resize a world token to the right size for the current scene scale. However, you should ensure that the scene has a suitable scale otherwise planets will be too big or too small to be useful.

On such a map, if you select another ship as a target when making spacecraft attacks, ranges to each target will be given, along with modifiers for target size.

Alternatively, you can not use the map and determine ranges yourself, or use a simple range tracker by using thrust points.

Combat Rounds

Space craft can be added to the combat tracker.

The ship's thrust and pilot's kill will act as an initiative bonus.

Crew

Add roles to a ship, and assign crew members to the roles.

There is a 'Make PIlot' action under the Pilot Role. This will make the current crew member the pilot, and it is their skill which will affect ship actions.

Gunners can be assigned to guns, and used to fire the guns.

Attack and Damage

Things implemented:

  • Damage to spacecraft

  • Damage multiplier for different sized mounts (turrets, barbettes, bays).

  • Damage multiple for spacecraft scale v human scale and vice versa.

Critical Hits

They will be recorded, but they aren't all fully implemented.

Cargo will be randomly destroyed.

Crew will not be randomly hurt.

Missiles

If a weapon is a missile, then a Missile Salvo actor will be created. This can be placed on the map to track position.

Point Defence and electronic warfare needs to be done manually.
